messageBody:
The following comments are from an off line discussion.

J. B. Rainsberger provides some insights which may be useful to all.

Basically, the question was, "If you create a test method that calls an updatePassword method and sends in an argument
that should throw an IllegalArgumentException, what do you put in the catch block?"


-------- Original Message --------
Subject: Re: [junit] Propagating Exceptions
Date: Tue, 26 Jun 2001 14:18:00 -0400
From: rainsber@ca.ibm.com
To: "Mike Duffy" <mike.duffy@cci-triad.com>

Ask yourself: "Do I need more detail than this?" Maybe nothing goes in the
"What goes here?" spot. If you only call method X and you expect
IllegalArgumentException, then do you need more than try { X(); fail("Got
here?!"); } catch (IAE success) {}?

You could check that the detail message matches or contains a certain
string, but when testing with exception classes you didn't create, you
can't always be as specific as you'd like without relying too much on
details you can't control.

In your specific case, perhaps don't throw IllegalArgumentException, but
create your own subclass InvalidPasswordException. Now you have total
control.

Good luck.

J. B. Rainsberger <rainsber@ca.ibm.com>

Thank you for your kind reply. I do understand the process in creating
your own exceptions.

However, what if you wan to test that an IllegalArgumentException is thrown
under the proper conditions (e.g., min
password length). If you create a test method that calls an updatePassword
method and sends in an argument that should
throw an IllegalArgumentException, what do you put in the catch block?

public void test_updatePassword() {

try {
instancePartnerWorker.updatePassword("abc");

fail("The argument newPassword is less than six characters and
an IllegalArgumentException was not
thrown.");

} catch (IllegalArgumentException e){

// What goes here?
}
}



rainsber@ca.ibm.com wrote:

> Do your exceptions have any useful attributes? If not, why not?
>
> Consider a server that provides a number of named services. I want to
write
> a test saying, "If I try to invoke a non-existent service, the system
> throws me an appropriate exception."
>
> public void testNonexistentService() {
> Server server = new Server("Some name");
> assertEquals(0, server.countServices());
>
> try {
> server.invokeService("doesNotExist");
> fail("How did I invoke a nonexistent service?!");
> }
> catch (NoSuchServiceException success) {}
> }
>
> The above test verifies that a "NoSuchServiceException" is thrown, but
the
> exception could be more specific. Let the exception store the server and
> service names so that I can check that not only was the exception thrown,
> but it's indicating that "doesNotExist" does not exist in server "Some
> name" and not some other service or some other server. Following is
> therefore better:
>
> public void testNonexistentService2() {
> Server server = new Server("Some name");
> assertEquals(0, server.countServices());
>
> try {
> server.invokeService("doesNotExist");
> fail("How did I invoke a nonexistent service?!");
> }
> catch (NoSuchServiceException success) {
> assertEquals("Some name", success.getServerName());
> assertEquals("doesNotExist", success.getServiceName());
> }
> }
>
> Now I must create an exception class "NoSuchServiceException" that is
> probably a RuntimeException and has those two attributes. I let the test
> tell me how specific the exception should be.
>
> Get the idea?
>

> rainsber@ca.ibm.com wrote:

> > Catch the exceptions you expect:
> >
> > try {
> > ...
> > }
> > catch (IExpectedThisException success) {
> > assertEquals(expectedValue, success.getSomeExceptionAttribute());
> > ...
> > }
> >
> > Throw the exceptions that you don't expect:
> >
> > public void testEjbs() throws RemoteException, FinderException, ... {
> > // EJB code
> > }
> >
> > If there's something "in between" where an exception represents a
> failure,
> > but not an error, then catch it and fail:
> >
> > try {
> > ...
> > }
> > catch (SomeKindOfFailureException oops) {
> > fail(oops.toString());
> > }
> >
